issues.description: The problem statement / UML specifies ExcellenceLand.excellentEnough as a boolean (lines indicate -excellentEnough: boolean), but the solution implementation declares excellentEnough as a String, uses a String constructor parameter and returns String from the getter. This is a structural type mismatch for a core attribute and will confuse students about the expected type and cause tests that expect a boolean constructor parameter/getter to fail.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the excellentEnough attribute a boolean in the solution (and template) to match the UML and problem text. Update the constructor signature to ExcellenceLand(double excellencyLevel, boolean excellentEnough, List<Ride> rides) and change the getter to return boolean (e.g., public boolean getExcellentEnough()). Ensure the template stub and any tests align with the boolean type.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares ExcellenceLand.excellentEnough as a boolean (line shows '-excellentEnough: boolean'), but the solution implementation declares the attribute 'excellentEnough' as a String and provides a String-typed getter and constructor parameter. Although the identifier name matches, the type difference changes the conceptual representation of the same entity and will confuse students who expect a boolean flag according to the UML and task description.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the UML: change the type of 'excellentEnough' in ExcellenceLand from String to boolean, update the constructor parameter and the getter to use boolean. For example, declare 'private boolean excellentEnough;', change the constructor signature to take a boolean for that parameter, and have 'public boolean getExcellentEnough()' return the boolean. This aligns the implementation with the problem specification and removes student confusion.
